utterances: Still, Jaschik says he doesn't expect the scandal to do lasting damage to the University of Illinois's reputation.
David Schaper, NPR New, Chicago.
MORNING EDITION from NPR News.
I'm Steve Inskeep.
And I'm Renee Montagne.
Just like the new Congress, we're on our way to Washington this week.
As Democrats prepare to take control, we're asking voters what's on their minds.
With a map in hand, we've been phoning people along U.S.
Highway 50.
Among others, we've met a California makeup artist, a Utah restaurant owner, and a museum director in Missouri.
You go a little bit further east and you reach Flora, Illinois, and that's where we found Dave Burt.
Mr.
Burt, welcome to the program.
Good morning.
So what have you been doing today?
We've been hauling wheat to the elevator.
And how's business?
We had a pretty good year, farming.
Our biggest problem this year was energy costs.
When diesel fuel goes up, and gasoline, and fertilizer goes up right with it.
And of course, you know, it costs that much more, not only to plant it and harvest it, but just like today, we're hauling grain some 60 miles roundtrip and the fuel cost is definitely a big impact.
Maybe it's just time for you to get a job at Wal-Mart.
No, this is good times, actually.
Oh, it is?
Okay.
Oh yeah.

It's exciting times for the farmer, but one of the things that I know that in the state of Illinois, for example, they're pushing the renewable fuels with ethanol, and I'm not so sure that for the health of the country that is what we should be doing in terms of burning food for fuel.
So my hope would be that they would pass some initiatives to let us drill domestically for oil.
Well now Mr. Burt, you've got a Democratic Congress coming in.
Democrats have talked about energy independence, but I'm not sure that their agenda is quite the same as yours necessarily.
I think they're thinking more in terms of conservation that oil drilling.

Well then the only other way that we're going to be able to conserve fuel is to raise gasoline to a price level where people quit using it recreationally, you know, which is going to hurt the economy, I think.
Well what's the countryside like as you drive on east into Indiana, which is where we're going next?
The roads get better.
(Soundbite of laughter)
As soon as you cross the state line?
As soon as you cross the state line, I mean it's like you've gone into a different world.
Indiana is a pretty state.
Well let's go right on over into Bedford, Indiana, which is where we found Gary Heichel, who's our next guest as we continue along Route 50.
And Mr. Heichel, we just heard a very complimentary description of your part of the state of Indiana.
What's it like there?
Ah, it's kind of laid back.
Good folks live here.
I've only been here since March.
I lived out in Springville, Indiana, which is out in the country.
Which - kind of kept to myself pretty much, with my music.
You're a musician?
Yeah, a songwriter.
And we're near John Cougar Mellencamp territory there I believe, aren't we?
Yeah, I was just by his place here, last week.
Now did you closely follow last fall's election?
I had no idea.
Time just slips away from me most of the time.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Did you vote?
No, actually, no, I don't do that either.
When I grew up in central Pennsylvania with my grandfather, the closest I got to politics was we had one of the Secret Service men, Davey Krause, when the Nixon administration was going on.
And I got to meet him, and he brought an autographed picture of Nixon up.
That's as close as I've gotten to politics.
Do you never vote?
Never did.
Hmm.
Well I gotta tell you, you're in the majority.
I know I am, and I've been thinking about it.
Maybe I get a little stupid and think, well, things have been going kind of good so far; they must be doing something right, what do they need me for?
But I guess that could change.
Well let's continue right along Route 50, here.
Looks like we're going to get all tangled up in the Ohio River as we'll pass through Cincinnati, Ohio and we'll end up in Milford, Ohio, which is where we found Jean Ackerman.
Ms.
Ackerman, welcome to the program.
Thank you.
What's Milford, Ohio like?
It's a small community, conservative, mostly small businesses; just friendly, outgoing, welcome.
What do you do for a living in Milford, Ohio?
My husband and I own a small retail meat market with a fudge kitchen inside, a catering department, a wine department.
And then of course we have the largest amount of feet of fresh-cut meat in southwestern Ohio.
Did you go and measure that?
My husband did.
How many feet?
I believe there's a little over 2,800.
That is a lot of feet of fresh-cut meat.
